text: forever yeah children forever let's meet
the age we want to be what how would you
wanna be you want to be a nine let's be
jumping forever mr. lonely is a new film
from director Harmony Korine it's his
first film in almost 10 years he gained
some notoriety and a little bit of
critical respect back in the late 90s
when he made Gummo and Julia and donkey
boy those were in many ways harsh
provocative but very interesting and
daring movies mr. lonely is also
interesting and daring but instead of
being harsh and provocative it's gentle
strange and disarmingly sweet it
imagines a world in which being a
celebrity impersonator is a kind of
special and unusual identity the main
character played by Diego Luna is a guy
who dresses up like Michael Jackson and
it doesn't really even look that much
like Michael Jackson he just feels
somehow that he is in tune with Michael
Jackson and we need a Michael we don't
have him Michael I wouldn't know what to
do and he meets and develops a crush on
a woman played by Samantha Morton who
dresses and as she says lives as Marilyn
Monroe did you ever talk about me she's
married to Charlie Chaplin and their
child is Shirley Temple and they all
live together in a commune in the
Scottish Highlands that's entirely
populated by these celebrity
impersonators
that's a very strange idea for a movie
and it could have been can't be cute
knowing and ironic but instead there's
something very sincere and heartfelt
about this movie and one of the ways
that that expresses itself is through
these beautiful images that Corinne
fills the screen with he's really just a
master of composition and camera
movement and color while the movie
doesn't quite hold together and it's a
little bit too oblique and elusive for
my taste it really leaves you with a
very unusual set of moods and feelings
and ideas and it's a movie that I think
will grow on me and will grow on anyone
who takes chance to go and see it
